lines.text:
[Rallying the South Essex]
I'm your colours. I Am.
The Prince of Orange. They wanted to give him command over me. Better counsel prevailed.
It's the French. Oh my god. Now they have guns.
Oh, they've always had guns, your royal highness. What they haven't always had is you as a target.

[to the Prince of Orange]
You, sir, are a silk stocking full of shit.
Your Regiment, Sharpe!
Prince of... South Essex! ADVANCE!
[regiment walks off towards the French]
South Essex Charge!

[Rebeque is talking to Sharpe about the Prince of Orange and his whores, when there is large bang]
That's his boots!

[on the Prince of Orange]
He did it again. How many more men will he kill? That's my commission gone to the blazes I dare say, but it had to be said.

[choking with grief]
Daniel Hagman... Harris... He won't kill anymore!

[to Doggett]
Oh now you have caused trouble!
[rides after Sharpe]

[to the Prince of Orange]
You did it again! Colonel Sharpe said you would do it again, and you did! All those men dead because you wanted to get out? You coward!
Doggett! His Royal Highness cannot be called a coward.
No, dammnit. No, not cowardice, not that. Just so he can dance and prance, and make high cockalorum, while men die? Horribly? It is too much, I declare, too much! I shall say it!

[after a second]
You sir, are a silk stocking full of shit!
Harris?
Hm?
What's your first name?

[speaking in Dutch to his men]
No! No! You can shoot better than that!

[has stumbled across Jane and Rossendale]
You!
Don't hurt me please!
And you!
[grabs Rossendale]
You dare to come! You dare to join! You dare to be in the same buggerin' army as me!

[chases Rossendale until Rossendale trips and falls]
Get up! Get up and fight!
[turns to the crowd]
Somebody give him a sword!
[turns back to Rossendale]
Do you have a friend?

[recognizing the duel challenge]
No no no no no, please!
Then give me the money, you can keep the whore you lilly-livered...
[feels the shame of being a cuckold, and draws his sword]
No, by God I'll fillet you anyway!

[intervenes]
Enough!
[looks down at Rossendale]
Get up.

[does not move his sword]
By God I'll fillet you also!
You will not!

[mutters in Sharpe's ear]
Richard, don't do it.

[sighs in defeat]
You tell him Harry.

[looking up, embarrassed]
I fell, just fell.
Tell him he can have the whore
[Jane stares at him in loathing]
but I want my money.
What do you want?
More pay would be nice.
Can't stand duels. You can't drink!

[in the thick of a massacre]
I can kill as well as you Sharpe!
Do you still want to see Boney?
More than ever.Might ask him for a job.
[the Prince of Orange rides to Wellington's side]
Good day to you. We're fighting Boney, you know. Indeed we are. This day, at the cross roads of Quartre Bras... He's been seen.

[skeptically]
Has he been?
We're holding the woods, I do believe... yes.

[looks around]
Where are your men?
Fighting... fighting.
[the Dutch troops stream past, clearly running away]
I stand corrected, highness. I know very little about uniforms, other than me own, but I could have sworn these was yours as is running. Ain't they?

[draws his sword]
Some of them, Lord Uxbridge, some of them.
[spurs after them]
Come back here, you cowards!
I never mind men running as long as they come back.

[to the retreating Dutch troops]
My lads, you look blown from your run. Come, do take breath a moment. Then we will go back and try if we can do better. Take heart, soon have some guns up. Uxbridge!
Wellington?
When?
Oh, they do come, I assure you. What of the Prussians. Any word at all?
I told the Prussians we'll support them but only if not attacked here. They'll have to fight without us today.
If your corps is coming up, as you assure me, how close do you think they are? I want them to clear that road, I want it handsomely arranged with guns.
Very close.
How close?
Close. Coming up.
[He turns around to look for them]
[as Wellington sits down to dinner, the night before the battle]
What do you do tomorrow?
What do you eat, Uxbridge?

[impatiently]
Much the same.
Does the army want for anything?
Damn it, what do you do tomorrow? What plans have you?
Plans?
I am second in command! I ought to know!

As soon as Napoleon Bonaparte tells me what *he's* going to do, I shall know what *I'm* going to do, and I shall tell you. But as Boney has not yet confided in me, I cannot confide in you. So, to your beef, Uxbridge.
[Uxbridge exits in a huff]

[under his breath]
Adulterous rogue.

[taking out a notebook]
What time?
What?
What time did it stop? The cannonade. I have it as ten minutes of midday, but the Duke likes it accurate, you see.
What time is it now?
Oh, uh...
[fumbles with his pocketwatch]
Four minutes after midday, save a few...
You'd best write down that they're coming, then.
Coming?
The French are advancing.
[Witherspoon looks into the woods, where a huge French column is advancing]
Ah, so they are. Thank you, my dear fellow, I might have missed that.
[as the French advance on La Haye Sainte, beating their drums and shouting "Vive L'Empereur!"]
In all the years that I've been fighting the French... I have become sick and bloody tired of that shite music that they play.
[as the French artillery commence fire, beginning the Battle of Waterloo]

[lifting a glass of sherry]
Gentlemen, I give you today's fox.
